div.p: A-la-mode PHLEBOTOMY NO GOOD FASHION: OR, THE COPY OF A LETTER TO Dr. HNGERFORD, Complaining of, and Intancing in the Phantatick Behaviour and Unfair Dealing of ome London Phyitians when they come to be Conulted withal about Sick Perons living at a Ditance from them in the Country.
Whereupon a Fit Occaion is taken to Dicoure of the Profue Way of Blood: Letting formerly unheard of, though now adays o mightily in Requet amongt vs here in England.
By RICHARD GRIFFITH of Richmond in Surrey. M. D. Formerly Fellow of Univerity Coll. in Oxon, and now Fellow of the Coll. of Phyitians of LONDON.
LONDON, Printed by T. B. for Joeph Hindmah, at the Black Bull in Cornhill. 1681.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
I Know 'twill be expected, and 'tis, I confes, no more than what is Reaonable, that I hould here give thee ome Brief Account of the Caues inducing me to make thee enuing Lines Publick. If either I, or another man have received any Peronal Injuries in Relation to our elves or our Profeions, what has the World to do with that? Thoe, and thoe only, are to be made Acquainted therewith, whoe Particular Concernment it is to
Arbitrate, and do Acts of Jutice between Man and Man. To raie a Hue and Cry for the Los of every Triffle, and et the Beacons a burning upon the Approach of every Petty and Inconiderable Veel? would make but a trange kind of Diturbance in a Kingdom or Commonwealth: And no les degree of Madnes may it appear to be, for Men of Private Condition to write Letters of Sad Complaints to one another about the Matters appertaining to their own Particular Affairs, and then to put them in Print when they have done, with an Epitle before an Epitle, and Solemn Appeals to the whole Body of the People to pas their Verdict upon the Cae, who are mot like to be in the Right, and who in the Wrong.

And then to make a Decription at large how uch an one was taken Ill,
and what everal Sorts of Medicaments were thought upon by one Phyitian, which were all again diallowed of by another; and o by that means, to well up a Publick Narrative with little ele beide an Account of their own Fewds and Janglings, and Paltry Dicontents may eem to be an Enterprize of jut as weighty a Concernment as the other was before, and undertaken to every whit as Wie and Ueful a Purpoe: Becaue if they do fall out or fall in, as the People are wholly unintereed in the Quarrel, o are they likely to be neither much the better nor the wore which Party oever gets the Victory. Is it not uual for mot men whoe Livelyhood comes in after the ame Manner to Wrangle and Squabble, and render one another as Depicable as they can, to the end that thoe who appear to be the Bravet Champions in the Encounter may be able to bear away the
Greatet Share of the Employment to their own Side? And is it not enough for the Spectators to be et a Laughing at them for their Foolery when they do o? But that Proclamation mut be made for all others that would be apt to pas by without taking the leat Notice of what had happened, to be invited to come in and deride them likewie.

Thee two, as they lie the fairet in the Way, o are they the mot Material of all other Objections beide, that I can think of; and could we but get clear of them, I ee no great Reaon to the contrary, but that the whole of what has been Propounded, did it not fail in ome Points relating to the Manner of its Performance, might be looked upon as Paable enough; but that is a Thing not at all to be either Diputed or Jutified by us here in this Place;
but rather to be left to the more impartial Determination of uch, as hall be willing to be at the Trouble throughly to examine it.

As for what concerns the former of thee, I have only this to plead on my own behalf, That notwithtanding the Intances put may indeed eem to have a Repect, but to one or two particular Perons at the mot. Yet the Reaon of the thing is of a much larger Extent as comprehending under it no les than a whole Community of Men; there being carce a Countrey Phyitian now living in England, but who either has been already, or ele at ome time or other in probability may come to be involved therein; and therefore what has been affirmed of one or two, may in a Sene proper enough be applied to them all in General: And then the Benefit ariing from the Memorandum's
given, can never be excepted againt as retrained unto a few.

And albeit it be carcely to be imagined for any actually Reident in the Country to be o invincibly Stupid, as not to be convinced before-hand, of the Truth of what they hall find aerted, either through their own Experience, or the Complaints of thoe they at ome times or other may happen to have had Communication withal. Yet ought it not however to be eteemed of as lot Labour, to be confirmed in the Belief of what they knew to be o, by the concurrent Tetimony of others beides themelves. The doing o friendly an Office may erve as an Additional Corollary to their Heap, and be ueful to them, if for no other purpoe, yet at leatwie to excite their Care and awaken their Diligence for the preventing uch Inconveniencies for time to
come, as without it might poibly have been o much the more apt to have befallen them.

But as for uch young Gentlemen, who are in a manner unacquainted with the World, and who living till in the Univerities, have both their way of Employment and Place of Reidency as yet wholly to chooe: Such an Allarm
• s this may prove to be of much greater Conequence to them; for they by making a due Improvement of o Seaonable an Advertiement, may conider the better how to dipoe of their own Affairs, and not be ennared in a Nooe all on the udden, they never o much as dreamt of, as thouands others have been before them, to the utter undoing both of themelves and Families, as might be eaie to hew how and which way; but that all is o manifetly dicovered in the Sequel of this
Tract. I hall therefore make the more hate to the other Objection as yet behind.

And here again, though the Examples produced may be but one or two for Number, yet are they virtually as many as the Inhabitants dipered up & down the whole Nation; who might all of them have been erved with the very ame Sauce, had they but fallen under the ame circumtances the others did, and but ent for the ame or uch-like Wie and Faithful Counellors to have afforded them their Aitance, or may yet in good time, when ever the like Difficult Occaion happens to preent it elf: And then neither can the Uefulnes of what has been Oberved be manely a • le to Exception upon the latter Score. Becaue all uch as in ucceeding Times hall chance to fall ill of any Dangerous Ditempers have an Item
given them, if they pleae to take • t, of divers Material Points; which o
• herwie perchance they would not have been altogether o well aware of. As firt of all to take it into their Serious Conideration, Whether or no it may not be much better to make a Beginning with a London Phyitian, if it mut • ome to that at lat, as a urer means • o engage him to the greater Faithfulnes and Circumpection in what he Undertakes.

Secondly, Whether having conult
• d with a Neighbour at the Firt, it may • ot be adjudged convenient to Adhere • o much the cloer to his Directions.

Thirdly, Or if it hall be held meet • o eek out for an Aitant, that may be Partaker of the ame Cares: It may • ot be good Advice to make choice of • Peron as well remarkable for Honety,
as Learning; it being the mot likely for uch an one to be Contriver of the leat Michief, as well as to be in a Capacity of doing the greatet Good. My Meaning is to have it well weighed, whether uch men as cannot be denied to have a Competent Stock of Learning in their Heads, but withal are known to have a great deal more of Pride and Malice, and other uch-like Naughty Principles in their Hearts may not be apt to pull down more with one Hand, than they are able to et up again with both, and o prove in the Iue intead of Helpers to be the greatet Hinderers of all.

Or Latly, to have it debated, Whether or no ome earnet Injunction t • deal clearly and uprightly in the Matters they are intruted withal, withou • either Prejudice or Humour, or Affectation of Vain Glory, or out of any
other By-repect whatever, beides purely the good and wellfare of the Patient they are ent for to Conult about, may be e're a whit uneaonable. I know ome will be apt to mile at this lat, as uppoing it to be a meer Folly to go about to oblige thoe by Obecrations and Intreaties, that could never be prevailed upon by any Sene of Honour and Concience, and the Engagements they have ometimes taken: But then they are uch as have neither Concience nor Honety, to which an Obligation (if to any thing) ought to be fatned; that we have been all this while peaking about, and o they are oon anwered.

Beides, 'Tis none of the mallet Obligations they lye under, to treat one another civilly as oft as they meet together in Conultation; which Rule, how well 'tis oberved, the many Slanders,
Backbitings, and ometimes open Reproaches, which are wont to fall out upon that Occaion, do more than ufficiently witnes: And then let any one hew me a Reaon why thoe that are fale to their Engagements in one Repect, hould not as well be the ame to them in another, whenever it uits with their Interet to be o? And though, 'tis true, a good Man may do well for the Sake of Virtue alone, and though he hould have no Supervior at all to overee him in his Actions: 'Tis neither impoible nor unlikely but that the Bad may receive the Suret Check of all to put a top to the fullet Career of their evil Practices from ome Accidental Coniderations; uch as is the Fear of Shame, and Cenure, and Publick Report: And if they have any feeling left them what the meaning of thee things is, 'tis carcely imaginable but that they hould have the Faculty
• omething the more quickened and rubbed up, when they perceive their Do
• ngs pryed into, and had in Supition by other men.

Some other things there are, which were all people but o Charitable or • ngenuous as to take in the ence they were either intended or did naturally • mport, would tand in little need of • n Apology, they are o Innocent and Harmles; as namely, the Initing for • o long a time together upon the Sicknes of a ingle Peron; the eeming Reflections that are made in ome Paages upon the Female Sex, and the caue of Scandal offered to all Phyitians • n general, by laying o foul Aperi
• ns to the Charge of ome of their Particular Members. But in regard there are o many turbulent Spirits in the World, apt to cavil at, and pervert the Meaning of almot every thing they meet withal, that is but capable of a wrong Interpretation as well as a right.
I hall, for their Sakes, and for the preventing any ill Conequences that might be apt to enue upon their ditorted Commentaries, crave leave to add a few words for the Vindication o • them alo.

In anwer to the Firt, of which i • may not be altogether unworthy the Noting, that the Compoing huge large Volumns, filled with nothing ele but the Obervations that have been made by Phyitians upon the variou • Etates of everal Dieaed People, and the Remedies applyed to each of them together with the different Succees and Events that have followed thereupon was never (that I could yet hear of looked upon by any (though the mo • Critical in their Judgments) as any matter of Aburdity at all: And then wha • jut Reaon can there be aignable, wh • the ame Favour hould not be allowe • of, when an Example comes forth unaccompanied and ingle by it Self, epecially
eeing uch a Cae is like to be o much the more narrowly ifted into, and et forth with all its Circumtances; whereas many things of a like Nature thronging in a Croud together, cannot be attended to with an equal Regard, but mut, and will of neceity prove an hinderance to one another.

Whence it often happens, that what might very well have deerved a more erious and thorough Diquiition, comes to be huddled over with too much Brevity; which in all Caes is no other than the immediate Parent of Obcurity, and the Grandmother of Confuion and Mitakes, and by that means a Neceity is occaioned of making Repetition of the ame things everal times over; as we find it in divers Authors, which had they been handled more copiouly at the firt, and debated upon with that deliberation which the matter might have required, might have erved but once for all; and thoe other
Tautologies which we meet withal o often afterwards, have very well been pared.

And then in the Second and Third Places, for the Reaon is one and the ame to both; becaue ome few of a Kind or Profeion have been repreented as Blameworthy; therefore, to imagin that either any others, or all the ret of thoe Orders, who neither are, nor ever were intended to be uch, hould find themelvs agrieved thereat, is jut uch another wild and fantatical Surmie, As to uppoe that all the Individual Perons belonging to any Community whatever, hould be either Wie, or Learned, or Good; if that could but be made out for an Hypotheis to build upon, then indeed the taxing of any one of the whole Rank, might well be interpreted an inuring of them all: As they ay it fares with the Strings of ome Muical Intruments <> a Room together, if wound up to
an equal height; touch one, and you would tir them all: But o long as the contrary is known to be mot undeniably true, it can be no Diparagement to the bet Societies in the World to have it poken, becaue o eaily to be proved that there have been, are, and ever will be ome Faulty perons amongt them. Nay, 'tis o far from being any Diminution at all to the Worth of thoe that are in no wie guilty, that it commends it but the more, and ets it off with o much the purer a Lutre: Becaue had there been no Vice, there would have been no Virtue; and were it not for the Badnes of ome Men and Women in the Wotld, there could never poibly have been any Good. Nay the very World it elf, etting aide Monters and Prodigies, and other uch-like Deformities of Nature, could never in any ound Sence have been aid to have been made perfect; becaue this Comparion above, gives Beauty and Ornament
to mot of the things that are found in it, which would have neither the one nor the other if conidered in themelves. VVe account ome Perons to be Dicreet, and Jut, and Temperate, but they are the Fools, and Knaves, and Debauches that make them uch. And thoe very Ladies which are wont to Attract the Eyes, and engage the Affections of almot every one they come a neer, little think how much they tand indebted to the Blemihes of ome of their own Sex for the place they hold in the good Opinion of their Admirers. And therefore I can ee no reaon why any VVomen, whoe Dipleaure is worth the erving, hould pretend to take any thing amis that can be aid of them as deerve to hear ill. Not only becaue there can be no great hurt in Slandering any one with a matter of Truth, but upon the very account of their own Interet: For if they are uch as mot VVomen would be thought to
be, and I, for my part, am willing to believe they are, unles the Faults and Midemeanours of thoe who are their Foils, had by ome means or other happened to have been rendred conpicuous: Thoe very Qualifications, upon the Score of which they are wont o highly to value themelves, had never in the leat meaure come to have been taken notice of.

And this might very well have ufficed for the anwering each of the two Particulars at once, might it have been but applied in the ame proportion it bears to both of them alike. But in regard o much has been poken in order to the excuing a word or two, and that when let fall but by the by only; becaue a little lenting upon that Sex, which is o much given to take Exceptions: Whereas the very Scope and Drift of the whole Deign has been for no other end (as the Title Page truly enough eems to intimate) then
the expoing the Unworthy Dealing of ome Phyicians to publick Scorn and Contempt. I cannot but hold my elf obliged in the bet ort I can, to bepeak the formable Opinion of thoe Learned and Worthy Perons, who though wearing the ame Titles, and inhabiting the ame Place with them, do yet (I believe) as much abhor and detet their Leiger du Main Tricks, as either I my elf or any other man; and I do hope, and ret pretty well aured, That as there has not been any one Syllable of ought poken by me intended to their Prejudice: So that neither it will be o undertood by them. I do from my Heart believe the Generality of Phyicians now living in London, to be the mot Able, Learned, and every way well qualified Perons of any that are to be found again of the Profeion throughout all Europe beide, as they have ever had the Honour, and that mot deervedly, to be accounted
of. The more then the pity, that thee their good Parts hould be abued to o ill purpoes, by ome rotten and corrupt Members amongt them; and o much the more need (one would think) there hould be to et ome Marks of ditinction to difference the one from the other. And if I out of a Fit of Zeal for the publick Good, rather than any great depth of Judgment, have been o little mindful of my own private Interet, as to et a helping hand to the promoting that which I conceived to be o honet an Undertaking; I hope no good Man will ee any jut reaon wherefore to be offended with me for it. I may perchance deerve omething of his Pity for intermedling in a Brangling Buines, which might have been much better for me, to have paed over in Silence, but urely nothing at all of his Dipleaure. Particular Premies can never include any ufficient medium, for the warranting any Univeral Concluions.
No more can the vicious Inclinations of ome few of a Profeion affix any jut matter of Ignominy upon the Reputation of thoe that are good; But enough of this has been already poken to under the former Head, which if it hall not be adjudged Satisfactory, I have only one hort Requet to make to them to whom it is not, and that is, That they would be pleaed but to make the Cae their own: as to peak the Truth of it, 'Tis impoible for any one rightly to apprehend the Concernments of another man, unles he do o.

Let uch but imagine themelves to have been at a great deal of Cot, and Pains, and Expence of Time more valuable than the other two; to have fitted and qualified themelves for an Imployment for the Service of their Country; and when they had ued their utmot Diligence in order to the attaining that End, and had at lat pitched upon a place of Abode every way commodious
to their liking: How would they whitle it to have a Malepert man of their own Rank (and ome years their Junior in that College, whoe very Statutes obliges each Member belonging to it, to a civil repectfulnes one towards another) without other provocation or Caue of ditat given him, other than what proceeded from the Malignity and Depravednes of his own cankred Nature;) ally forth amongt their Patients, and there betir himelf the bet he could to poes their minds with wrong Notions of their Ditempers and prejudices againt all rightful ways of Cure taken by them, and all this out of a wanton Humour to bring them into a Direpute with their Neighbours, and to convert the good opinion they might otherwie have been apt to have had of them into a meer Loathing and Abhorrency.

Nay, let me yet put the Quetion a little further home, and ask them, Whether
or no, if they had right on their ide, and were able to make it appear o to the World, they would forbear to ue the only means that was left them, for the jutifiing themelves and Actions, for fear of giving offence to uch as had no jut reaon to take any; and o out of I know not what crupulounes of fancy uffer their own Credits, and the lives of their Patients, o oft as the ame Project came to be renewed, to lye at the mercy of thoe who never had, nor were never like to have any regard at all to either. If they ay they hould not, as 'tis mot probable they will, then neither am I by their own confeions to be blamed for what I have done; but if they hould, though the groundles crupuloity of ome be no warrantable Rule for others to take example by; I care not much however, for this one time, if I do ubmit my elf to the mot rigorous everity even of their own Award; and o let them cenure me as
they think fit. And now I have made this bold challenge, I cannot foreee that o great hazard I am like to run thereby; becaue to be a Sot and a Dunce and an utter Ignoramus are the highet of Titles, the learned Rabbies, I have been endeavouring to decypher by their good would ever allow us poor Country Phyitians to be in any capacity of attaining unto; as the contant eries of their deportment towards us, and ometimes their dicoures bolted out occaionally make evidently enough to appear: And then I'd fain know what initer Accident that can poibly befal us in any undertaking we et about, can render our Perons more contemptible or our Condition much wore. But be it as it will, whatever may become of me and my mall concernments when the buines is brought to the uphot; I do not altogether depair but that (as it falls out with the unhappiet Projectors) ome benefit may
chance to redound to others, though I my elf hould be made a loer thereby, and that will be the compenation for the prejudice I am put to utain, every way as ample as I deire.

It was, for ought I know, and, which is omewhat more, am apt to believe, and now and then when I think upon it eriouly to pleae my elf (I confes) with the conceit thereof) prove an occaion of the aving much ueful Blood and Spirits in the Bodies of a multitude of good people, who upon the reading over the Arguments contained in this little thing (though proecuted I mut needs acknowledge with weaknes enough) hall not be altogether o forward to lend an ear to every plauible pretenion, as otherwie they would have been.

And 'tis not altogether impoible, but that ome who by one chance or other may happen to perue thee Lines, and are withal concious to themelves of having deerved the Character they
hall find betowed upon them (though 'tis very likely withal they'd ne're be brought to acknowledg o much) may when they perceive their Actions taken notice of, be induced o far forth to reform their manners, as not to inult over their equals in every thing but pride and conceitednes, with half that dominering Lordlines that formerly they were wont. And it be but out of fear that as the thing is come to be commonly known, o the next time they come to act it in publick, it may as publickly be laughed at.

And to peak the plain Truth of the matter, though I all along make my elf a party principally concerned; the occaion that has been offered is admitting of no other way of management. Or at leatwie this being the bet that my dull and barren fancy was able to ugget to me; yet the main Scope I have from firt to lat intended, has layen couched under thee two particulars before-mentioned, which if I obtain, I hall have
had my end; but if I mis of it, though every thing ele hould ucceed that may eem deireable upon any, or indeed all other accounts beides whatever, it will ignifie but very little or nothing to me. But I both mut, and hall for ever look upon my elf to have been totally diappointed.

As for what concerns the latenes of this Publication, o long after the occaion given: I have only one hort word to alledge in the vindication of my elf, which is, That though I had finihed what I have now written timely enough yet there being ome things contained in it of a reflecting nature, which could not be avoided. And I being then engaged in a buines, the mot important of all others to the concernments of Humane Life; which was not to be medled withal and any thing like Controverie at the ame time. I was in a manner compelled to give repit to the one, till I had fully accomplihed the other.

HAving been lately informed of a pleaant paage befalling you in your practice concerning your Patient. Sir H. F. I have made bold to be a little curious in enquiring into the truth thereof; and o much the rather, becaue the Catatrophe excepted in very many particulars, more than a little reembling a Cae I have had of my own.

I was given to undertand how, that after Sir. H. F. upon a Fall he had received near Windor, was committed to your care. A Phyician from London, by the importunities of ome friends of his, was brought down to viit him. How that the many Arguments of their Dicoure inited upon almot all the way they came, was to bewail the lamentable Condition of the unfortunate Gentleman, whoe hard hap it had been to catch his harm o far ditant from London; the only place (as they conceived) where the means of Relief in that and the like dangerous miadventures was to be ought for;
That his Lady was much to be blam'd for not looking out for better advice ooner, and for having o little reaon with her, as to relie upon the fumbling skill of a poor Countrey Doctor.

How that the Learned Man, o oon as ever he was carried into the Parlour, was oberved bitterly to inveigh againt the irregularity of your Precriptions; without o much as taking time to ee any, or hear any account given of what had paed before his coming thither; mot magiteriouly to have iued forth his orders for the taking away of thirty Ounces of Blood from your Patients Arm, Peremptorily alledging there was an abolute neceity for o doing: The only poible cruple remaining with him, being this; whether or no uch wholeom advice might not come omewhat of the latet, through the upine neglect of thoe foolih people who had been all this while about him to o little purpoe; as the uual pretence upon uch occaions is wont to be with all the Fraternity of like Principles with himelf; o that if the Buines had come to have ucceeded well, the credit of the Action, had been wholly his, if otherwie, the Odium and Digrace thereof had fallen to your hare. A pretty trim Invention this, and a cheap way of gaining glory to
ones elf; becaue hazarding nothing at all the mean while for it; unles it be a Patients life; or another man his good name; or o forth: A couple of petty and inconiderable things.

I hear, how that the Lady was a little urpriz'd at uch unwonted confidence; and conidering with her elf; that he had lot Thirty Ounces already, was not altogether o forward as was expected, to give entertainment to this o udden a motion; whereupon he was everely chidden for her waywardnes; and given further to undertand, that unles his commands were punctually oberved, her Husband was, in reaon, to be looked upon as no other than a lot man; and o he might do even as he pleaed, chue whether he would have his Life aved when it was offered, or not: But he, it eems, being a Peron to be wayed with ome thing ele, beides paionate words, and big looks, remained utterly diatisfied with thee his hatie concluions, and abolutely refued to follow his directions, unles hapning to be econded by your approbation: that the Doctor was bemadded thereat, threatned a departure out of Town, at break of day, next morning, (pretending I know not what urgency of occaions) unles your more early arrival there hapned to prevent him. All
which ubterfuges not erving his turn; but you appearing beyond expectation, and both diliking and confuting his councels, and they thereupon being rejected as unafe; I am credibly informed the Gentleman to have been retored to ome memory again, and as well recovered of his Malady (all circumtances duly conidered) as would reaonably have been expected.

If it be o, Sir, I heartily congratulate your afe ecape, from this notable underminding tratagem, that was o artificially contrived, for the blowing up of your reputation, and glad I am with all my heart, that the inventer thereof (be he who he will) was o luckily catched in the ame trap, he had deigned for another. Truly uch a facetious tory as this is, deerves to be laught at right heartily; becaue ending Commically: but had the Plot taken effect, and the blame of the micarriage lighted upon your head, together with the los of your Patients life to boot, • 'de fain know, how either you, or the wiet man living in your tead, could have been able to have holpen your elves.

Give me leave to tell you, Sir, that you have run a kind of deperate hazzard; becaue happening to be brought of by a meer contingency, all the ecurity you had being bottomed upon the light Bais, of but a ingle
womans opinion: And where there is one in that or a like cae, the deciion of the point being referred to their arbitrement, would have given it on your ide, there are five hundred would have inclined to the oppoite party; and have been apt to have cryed out without any further examination of the matter, that the doctor from London had aid it, and it mut needs be o: Ay indeed mut it, Ay and all that, and a great deal more; and this had paed for an argument as irrefragable as demontration it elf: as good have et your elf againt a Torrent with a pitchfork, as to have preumed to have muttered the leat illable in oppoition againt it. But all mut have been done, and you mut e'ne have uffered: There had been no remedy: For if he had dyed, no body had killed him but you, for not cauing him to be let blood in a ufficient quantity ooner. But if he had happened to urvive, then the Gentleman from London, had hewn himelf an incomparable Artit and performed an unexemplified cure, not only aved a man's life, that's a matter of mall moment with uch rare Practicioners, but what is omewhat more dificult, retored him to his enes and memory again: which without the interventions of his happy aitance had been irrecoverably lot. Then had not
only the Patient himelf, but his Dependents and Family been indebted for their preervation, to this mot excellent peron: And it had been an obligation of o endearing circumtances, as never to have admitted of a plenary recompence by any poible acknowledgments, that could for ever after that have been paid him: Then had he rode back to London in mot triumphant maner, vaunting and boating in all the companies he had come into of the happy reliefe he had given to one in the country, jut at the very intant of being cat away, through the ill mannagery & want of skill of one that paed for a Doctor amongt them. And then the Country Doctors, they mut have been frumped and coffed at; jut as the poor Curates are wont to be at an Act or Commencement, and forced to look imply, o of't as they had chanced to meet with any that had been dipoed to have been pleaant with them. And now what a ad and woful condition are you, and I, and a hundred more of us in, who by the inaupiciounes of the Planets we were born under, are condemned to take up our Abodes in Country villages, to be thus always liable to uch diadvantages as thee are, and left to the mercy of a part of extravagant hotheads, to put tricks upon us at their pleaure.

He that is a Heathen in his principles, and a meer Atheit in his practice, in fine, that is either a fool or a knave, or both or all together, whether he be Emperick, or Chirurgion, or Apothecary, or Legal Phyician, if coming but fron London, and dignified with the Title of a City Doctor, he carries all before him; and is at liberty to make havock of us, with the turning of a finger, in pight of all the defence in nature, we are capable of making for our elves; Unles through their own hair-brained, rah actions they happen to be plunged into a manifet aburdity; as in the cae but newly recited; and another of mine parallel to it as hall be hewed anon.

'Tis true if he be a man of uprightnes & integrity, as there is a number of uch in this City, to give them their jut due: then he either Jutifies what was done formerly, if in • his concience he believes the Phyitian to have proceeded according to the rules of art. But if otherwie: he fairly debates the matter with him, and labours either to convince him by making it appear where the mitake • ay, and is willing upon your reaons hewn
by the other to be overcome by him: and brought over to his opinion.

But if on the other hand as is not eldome een (and we have already uppoed) he proves to be diingenious and bae, and devoide of that moral honety, which all Phyitians by their education, and ome by vertue of their relation to particular Societies are more epecially obliged to, as there is no profeion of men whatever, but mut of neceity have ome that are bad amongt them. Then he projects all the ways he can how to alve his own credit, & conign the other over to the condemning power of the giddy multitude, who as they are always ready to take up the mot malicious landers upon Trut without o much as examining the reaonablenes of them, whether likely to be true or fale; o are they as indutrious to improve a calumny to the utmot; and help it forward with all the agravating circumtances, it can poiibly admit of.

He uually tels them for his part, that truly he could have wihed it had been his fortune to have been ent far ooner. Several things being proper to be done at the beginning, which are not altogether o eaonable at the full height of a ditemper, much les at what time Nature is almot overcome; but that which he precribes is the only
thing as the cae then tands poible to do the party good, and if that will not, he knows nothing ele can.

There are degrees of wickednes, and if the man be not fully fledged therein, it may be this reprehenion hall erve the turn, which though but gentle in comparion of the unmercifulnes of ome others, yet (if believed) is of ufficient validity to clip the wings of his Antagonits (for uch he eteems and uch he takes him to be,) o as to keep him from ever oaring over-high in the good opinion of his neighbours. But now if he bent to be michievous indeed, either through the propenity of his own nature or prompted to be o by the intigation of others: Then he goes a down right way to work, and finds fault with every kind of thing right or wrong that has been made ue of, before his coming: And all the quetions he makes are rais'd for no other intent whatever, but meerly to deprave.

Was the Patient let blood, why what cools or chils him? There being more need of Addition then Subtraction, of pouring freh into his veins (could it conveniently be effected) rather then letting any out, becaue in this cae the ditemper is to be carried off by fervent and a more quick Circulation of the blood, whereas now it Retagnates and Suffocates
the man, who might have done as well as any one in England, had he not mot unfortunately happen'd to have been abued and over-tampered withal.

But if there was no blood at all taken away, why then the cae becomes clearly altered, and that was the only Remedy Imaginable, & ought to have been celebrated upon any condition; but now 'tis too late, the humors being all quarred and etled about the Noble parts, which might eaily have been drawn away by Revulion when time was. And then he gives a grave no • with his head, and a hrug with his houlder as intimating ome wore buines then all that to lye behind, which he good man out of meer modety and pity to the others ignorance, is heartily ahamed to make mention of.

If he finds he hath been purged pretty titely, that has utterly dejected Nature: if but gently, then it has done the more michief, by tirring the humors only, and not throughly removing them, if moderately and between both extreames, then 'twas wholly improper, and hould not have been done at all, but he hould rather have been weated or vomited, or any other coure taken with him then that which was, and the like is to be aid indeed of any other application what ever. All which, and a great deal more, being
mot maliciouly uggeted by him, and with the ame Rancorounes of mind entertained by the Goips of the place, (I peak in the general, & would have my words taken as they are intended, in reference to the whole Englih Nation) who are always ready at hand to make their obervations how matters go; Away they run with it immediately, and happy is that Woman that can make the firt tep over her neighbours threhold, to carry a Report of thee lamentable Tidings; how that the Doctor from Lond, is jut now come, and ays there might have bin an other gets coure • aken with the Patient than was; & had he bin but ent for ooner, he could mot undoubtedly have aved his Life. Upon which, without farther proof, taking all for granted to be as 'tis related, they both lift up their hands to Heaven, and bles themelves, that one who pretends any thing to Phyick, hould be o trangely overeen; & yet now they think • on't again, who could ever have expected any other from him; for they, for their parts, never took him for any other then a pittiful hallow-brain'd man; And this puts them • n mind how uch a one, and uch a one di
• d under his hands, and they lay much after • he ame manner too, and none of them were blooded neither, and truely they be
• ieve them to have all gone after the ame
way, and to have been meerly detroyed for want of an able Phyitian.

I'de have uch illy ouls as thee are, but conider a little with themelves, whether the place where Phyitians have their education be not one and the ame to all; and when they have done that, perue the weekly bills of Mortality in London, and ee if they don't find ome figures there as well as all Cyphers; Nay if the Numbers of their dead do not equal, to ay no more, thoe amongt us in the Country, all due proportions being alow'd; & then let all the world judge if thee bold Undertakers be not hugely to be credited, that can have the impudence to talk thus

There are ome Stratagems never to be made ue of above once; and if they do happen to come about a econd time, are ure to be dicovered, provided againt, and bafled but here is a piece of Artifice beyond all Precedent, never to be worn Threadbare or ou • of fahion, but like the never failing Cordial it elf holds out everlatingly; and recour • may be had to it upon every occaion, An • as it has been Practied time out of min • (though perchance never publickly declaimed againt before now) o is it at length become hereditary, pleads a kind of Precription, and paes for currant even from Generation to Generation; it being by contan •
obervation, found exactly calculated to the Meridians of all Country parihes in and throughout England.

And if we conider over and above the length of it's duration, and vatnes of its extent, the weetnes of the Cutom it elf, and how throughly it has been natched by a great many of thoe, whoe interet it is to have it till kept up, we mut needs conclude it a task exceeding full of difficulty, let what can be aid againt it, ever to procure it totally to be laid aide again; and it be but for thee two reaons following: Firt of all, That it is a Project making uch dead ure work then ever 'tis put in Practice. Secondly, that it is o eaily performed. For 'tis but a bold mans crying out againt a wrong coure, and his being ent for too late, and there is a firm foundation laid for the raiing what ever malicious upertructure Mr. Slanderer hall Judge convenient, and he who is but qualified according to that mot excellent Character we have been all this while making a decription of, and has once let fly thee words; is ipo facto upon that very account perched up above the common Standard of all his equals, and veted with an Authority far urpaing the abolutenes of any Judge; for whereas a Judge is to act by vertue of his commiion barely, and has his
power limited and circumcribed by the known Laws of the land, whereby he is under a neceity of following the tract of a dozen plain Country-men, the Verdict of every one of which is to take Precedencie of his entence; here's one has the Law put into his own hand; or rather indeed; who makes his own Lit his Law, and takes upon him to Arraign, Judge, and Condemn at meer Random and Peradventure. A Pih, and a Tuh, and a ditorted countenance, are of authority ufficient to dipatch the credit of as good or a much better Phyitian then himelf in a breathing while, if happening to have the place of his Reidence without the Precincts of the City-wards: And the very name of a Country Doctor puts in a bar of Exception to all he can either ay or do; and in a word renders him a meer outlaw to the leat pretence of claim, to either civil repect or fair uage: And all they who are thus exalted above them, look upon themelves as priviledged to trample them to pieces, like o many Worms or Muhromes, as often as the haty mood chances to be upon them, 'tis an ancient cutom 'tis true, as has been uppoed; and that's all that can be aid for it: But 'tis as wicked as unreaonable; indeed o very wicked a one, as that, though it may, and does oftentimes no doubt Miniter occaion
of laughter to fooles, and uch as who, o they can but be merry, care not at what rate it is they purchae their preent patime; yet would it if well thought upon, et a conidering man a trembling to ponder with himelf what are wont to be the fruits thereof in the horrid conequences that do attend it.

And I could wih that all uch, as cannot but know themelves to be highly guilty in this particular, my meaning is of oppoing and thr • atning the depied men we have been all this while peaking about, and that for no other reaon, then that no reaon at all which has been likewie aigned by us, would but a little lay the matter to heart perchance the diverion they hall give themelves would not be altogether o full of merriment as ometimes it has been, and the forethoughts of an after rekoning might prove ome allay to the great contentment, many are apt to fancy to themelves in their chewing the Cud upon the blated Reputations of other men. For the thing however light and trivial it may haply appear to Vulgar eyes, is not o in its own nature, but to be reflected upon by uch as will Judge rightly of it, under a far different Notion: becaue when once this common bank of charity comes to be tumbled down
tis eay to dicern what an Ocean of inconveniencies, and thoe none of the meanet ort neither, tand ready to enter immediately upon the breach; Becaue he that has once hewn himelf a buie body in endeavouring to prove his Brother a fool: 'Tis ten to one if he do not in the next place dicover himelf to be an Errant Knave, by adventuring upon thoe mad precriptions which otherwie he would have been ahamed of: For has the other taken a wrong coure indeed, and has he aid it then? rather then to give his own tongue the lie, he is engaged in point of credit to run counter to all the other party has done before him. And when once maters arrive to that height it may very well be upected that he who made but little concience of breaking the ninth Commandment, will be as regardles of violating the Sixth; and he who could think it no crime at all, to bear fale witnes againt his Neighbour, will with as little regret of concience, be inclined to the Commiion of Murder: Epecially when it may be brought about after an indirect way: And when egged on thereto by Pride and Malice, and a fearlenes of ever being called to an account; but intead thereof being o urely provided of a Cloak-Father on whom to lay the obliquity of the
Action, in cae of its happening to be earched into. This makes him all for Projects, and experiments and trying of concluions.

Nero, when he had et the City of Rome on fire, could afford to make the better patime at the flames thereof, becaue he had the Chritians ready at a dead lift, to entitle to his wickednes: and jut o, and no otherwie do thee michievous and ill natured ort of men erve the poor Country Phyitians when ever they come amongt them, let who will enflame the reckoning, they are evermore put upon it, to pay the hot: Becaue they and none ele, in cae the Patient happen to dy, are to be accounted of as his Murtherers; but if he chance to ecape, as the only intruments of bringing his life into jeoperdy. So that fall back, fall edge, they are certain evermore to lie next harms way. And take the Dilemna by which Handle you pleae, either is like to prove but a wrong one to them. The others like his holines, are not o much as capable of commiting the leat overight, or if they do amis, by a trange kind of tranmutation, their Vicious acts are all turned into virtues, only by becoming theirs. It puts me in mind of ome great Commanders in a Sea-fight, who they ay after they have been
inconed in Cable, and inveloped about with Cordage, even from the head to foot, are then fiercet of all, to give forth their orders for the joyning of the battel: and after the ame manner do thee prime Artits let out their mad receipts upon the bodies of the mierable Patients, and when they have done that, tand by, and ee how well Nature and the Dieae combate together, and are all the while (to the praie of their great prudence, be it poken) free from danger, and out of Gun-hot themelves.

It trikes me with amazement, omtimes when I think on't, that the beotted Relations that are about the ick party are not offended at uch a fulome way of Procedure, but can be content to hear them out in what they have to ay, and uffer them to go on in a landering backbiting way, without check or controll, as ome do, o as to fleh and encourage them in this their ly kind of Knavery, and 'tis a wonderful trange thing to me, that they don't urge them to make good what they ay face to face, eeing the parties are o near together, who are of thee different perwaions, and eeing it may be done with o little trouble, to the end they may be the better enabled to come to the knowledge of the truth of the buines, and to pas ome little etimate how
matters tand themelves, though every Man is not a Phyitian, yet he mut be a very dolt indeed, who is not o far forth a Mater of his own Reaon, as to undertand ence when 'tis poken upon o common a Subject, and their are few by-tanders at a bar of Jutice, but upon a faithful opening of the caue on both ides between the parties, may be able to give a gues omething near the matter where abouts the iue is like to ret. Whereas they, who have an ear only for the Plaintiff, can never Judge of things impartially; but mut unavoidably be Subject to mitakes and incertainties, and it be but for this only Reaon, becaue the knowledge they are capable of having, is no more than contingent; if happening to be true, well and good: 'tis more than he who receives the information, could reaonably have been aured of, and conequently ought not to acquiece in; becaue it was equally probable that it might have been fale. So that albeit in the profound Myteries of Artificial wrangling, it be looked upon by thoe who are well Vered therein, to be a huge tep towards the carrying of the Caue, to be able to cry Whore or Thief firt: Yet amongt ober and dicreet perons, the Cae is far otherwie; and that very Circumtance of Pre-occupation, in drawing up the Charge
againt another, intead of aggravating the Crime, does but abate the Clearnes of the Tetimony given in, and render the Complainants Allegations o much the more upitious.

To peak hardly behind ones back, and to be the Inventer of little detracting Stories, to the Dipraie of another Man, who may be uppoed in the Opinion of the world, to tand upon Grounds equal with ones elf, is a practice o mean and ungentile, and creeping bae, that 'tis a Riddle to me, that any who does but pretend to either Learning or Parts, or an ingenuous Education, hould ever condecend upon the mot tempting provocation, to make ue of it. What then we hall think of thoe who can peak moothly to a mans face, and yet upon the turning into another Room, o oon as ever they can fit themelves of an opportunity and place to vent their Malice in, mut be darting out their landerous Suggetions againt thoe they jut before eemed marvellouly to approve of? This is an Action o purely Diabolical, and mells o hot of Brimtone, that thoe Notrils mut be dull indeed, that cent it not at the firt Breath. It can be reembled to nothing more fitly than the killing a man when fallen fat aleep, or the tabbing of one behind,
what time he leat of all thinks on't. Surely all uch as have hearts bad enough to propound the doing of uch vile things as thee, if their Wit were but proportionable to their pight, one would think however, they hould be deterred from the performance of them; becaue if their meaning come once throughly to be undertood, as 'tis plain enough to every indifferent capacity that it hould; they might very well expect to meet with a good mart Chiding, intead of a welcom Entertainment, and o no doubt they ometimes do, as in the Cae but newly intanced in, and divers others, which every ones Experience may be able to furnih them withal. But uch, alas! is the Folly and Madnes of the World, that People are generally o tame, as to uffer themelves to be mierably impoed upon by thee palpable Abues; and under a pretence of having their Eyes opened, are content to be led about by the Noes any whither; they are made to believe, that a trange Cure, (uch as theirs is, be it what it will) can never be wrought but after a trange and extraordinary manner. Their own Doctor, poor man! 'tis true, might haply do well enough, were he to wade in ome hallow Stream he had been acquainted with before; but as the Cae tands, he is now quite our
of his Depth, and at a plunge what to do, and which way to turn himelf; that is in plain Englih, les daring and adventurous about mad projects than themelves; and when once they have brought imple people to that pas to wallow any thing they'd have them, then let them alone to make the bet of their eaines of Belief; for now they have gained the point they aimed at, and like the Wolves in the Fable, when they had perwaded the Sheep to leave off the Company of the Dogs, whom they pretended to have had ome evil Deign upon them, have it in their power to deal with the wretched defenceles Creatures as they lit, and worry them at their pleaure.

The Daughters of old Pelias, when they were once throughly poeed with an opinion of their Fathers being made young again, what deperate undertaking was it that they either crupled or boggled at: the Poet tells us, that he who was the mot Pious above all the ret, hewed her elf the mot forward, and active intrument, in cutting the Old mans throat, and draining his very heart blood out, and all out of a ridiculous hope that much better and freher might be transfus'd into the room of it; which dutiful Office, o oon as ever they had performed, away flies he who had given them this
good Counel, hurried by a pair of Winged Dragons in the Air; and o they were finely left in the Lurch, with the Ghotly Spectacle of a Father's murdered Body before their eyes to gaze upon, and to bewail their own Credulity when it was too late.

The parallel is the ame to a hairs breadth, in the Cae we have been decribing. The Patient waxes ill, and upon Summons, down comes a man of rare Parts and profound Skill (or is believed to be uch at leatwie, and then 'tis the ame thing in ome repects, though not in all) and he looks gruff, and talks big; and uually the more extravagant his Dicoure is, the more 'tis admired by thoe who deired his Aitance; for hould there be any reaon to be given for what he ays, that would utterly poil its Excellency; becaue capable of being undertood, and appearing like omething vulgar and common, which they did not expect to hear from him. And then o oon as ever the Word of Command is given, though perchance o hatily, that 'tis impoible for any mortal Wight living within o narrow a Compas of time as is then taken, to arrive to the perfect knowledge of all Particulars neceary to be conidered of: Yet notwithtanding all that, without o much as examining what proportion it may
bear with the preent Exigency of the Party, or uffering others to do it for them; What running, what hurrying, what poting, what packing, to have it peedily put in execution! Every Minute eeming even years till the Will of the Learned be fulfilled. And when the Remedy does come to be made Trial of, intead of growing better, it may be the Patient becomes much wore than he was before; and if it be a deperate one as is not eldom een, then immediately upon the applying of it, he falls downright into a inking condition, and o dies away under their hands; and then they look upon one another like a company of Amazed, Giddy-Brain'd and Beotted Wretches; and whatever they confes with their Mouths (if they have any kindnes at all for their deceaed Friend) wih in their hearts at leat-wie, they had been better advied.

As for his part who did the Michief, to carry home the Comparion, he is far enough out of hearing, before ever the effect of his wretched Counel comes to take place; and when he knows it, o little is he concerned thereat, as that he is in as fair a way as ever for the trying uch another Experiment. And the next time he is invited out upon a like occaion, the very elf ame Game comes
to be played over again, ome few Circumtances of Time and Place only excepted; and he puts the ame Tricks upon Phyitian, Patient and By-tanders, and abues every one of them in their Order, as has been already hewn; and o he runs round in a Circle, and no one knows how to trap him; • ay, ten to one, if ome of the mot able Goips of their Tongues upon the Place, don't take his part for all this, and jutifie every thing he has either aid or done, if it be but meerly to maintain matter of Argument to dicoure about, or to render their own Phyitian the more ridiculous, or for • ome other vile Reaon not at all deerving • o be enquired into.

And this I have ever perwaded my elf • o have been one main Reaon why o very few Phyitians, however otherwie Learned and honet men, yet if happening to live without the Verge of the City of London,, eldom or never to come to attain to the Greatnes of an Etate equal with them, who either are Inhabitants of the City it elf, or ele happen to have the Place of • heir Abode at a more remote ditance from • t, meerly upon the account of iuing forth of the ill-Natured Men above mentioned, upon their ick Patients who, let them behave themelves never o warily, advie never
o regularly, or to have been never o happy in their Practice; all's one for that, a hundred to one but that at ome time or other they hall have a Slur put upon their mot innocent Actions, which hall both ully their Credit, and bring their Perons into a Direpute; Calumny being ever of that defiling Nature, that like the Dirt raked out of the Channel, if it be but lutily et on, it hall very rarely be o wahed out again, as not to leave omething or other of a tain behind it; epecially, if happening to be performed by a Party, who in cae of underdoing, is in all likelihood to be condemned to the very ame Penalty himelf.

'Tis true indeed, there are two things, which conidered of barely in themelves, render it an extream difficult Matter for any Countrey-Phyitian whatever, to arrive to any eminency either of Etate or Reputation: But if the Acceion of what we have been peaking of, happen to fall in likewie then next to impoible.
