But inamuch as Nature is uppoed to bear o great a Hand and Sway over them, o as to furnih them with Dipoitions, Habitudes, and Inclinations, in a word to have the Guidance of them in many repects, much after the ame manner that an Arrow is directed to the Mark, or a Ship Steered towards the Harbour: uch Expreions are aptly enough uited to the Nature of the things they are deigned for, and apprehended by uch as either ue or have them without any Difficulty at all.

So that the Circulation of the Blood being known to be much more ueful than the Act of Nourihing the Body, and that the ame Act of Nourihing the Body, has been at ome times, and is uually forborn to be exercied, whether it be in cae of Nature her being better imployed elewhere, or whether it be for lack of a Supply of uch Contribution as the Body was wont formerly to be furnihed withal; what hinders but that it hould as well give place here (that is to ay, whereever Phlebotomy hall be made ue of, eeing
'tis all one in ome Sene to be disfurnihed of what we actually had, and not to be upplied with what we hould have had, and be upended for ome little time, o long at leatwie till the preent harms may admit of a Reparation, which be it more, or be it les, if any at all, will be found ufficient for our purpoe; becaue, as has been already hewn, the Act of Nutrition, if upended at any time, mut unavoidably infer an Abatement to be made upon the whole Duration of Mans Life; I ay, the Duration of Mans Life, in regard the two primitive Qualities, o often before mentioned, and which are held to be the Maintainers of it, are o inevitably cut hort thereby; and then the whole duration, not only becaue 'tis impoible to Subtract any one ingle Unite from the vatet Number that can be named, without an impairing to the total Sum, or take away the mallet Particle imaginably from any Species of continued • uantity, without making it les than it was before; but as being willing to comprehend thereby any poible Alterations, greater or les, whether preent or future, that may poibly be occaioned thereby; nay, though they hould be of o low and gradual a Production, as could not well be taken notice of all on the udden, by one tranient and ingle view.

There being very many things in Nature, which, though falling directly under the cognizance of humane ene, when conidered of altogether, may yet be far enough from being accounted of as uch, if divided into Particles, and mall Tractions, and a repect be to be had to the precie manner of their being brought forth. The Gras of the Field increaeth daily at almot every eaon of the Year, and the Bodys of Vegitables and Living creatures, till uch time they arrive at their perfect growth, are inceantly paing from a les Etate unto a greater, and yet who the mot harp ighted amongt you, can pretend to an Infallibility of Judging the Senible Alterations wrought either in the one or the other; and the very ame Proportion holds in the Determination of mot things that is obervable in their Increae; 'tis to be confeed indeed, that after ome Paue made, and Competenty of time taken, to make a comparion between the things themelves, 'tis very poible to make a due Etimate of what may have happened, but that is not o much the Quetion in debate; 'tis the hortnes of time, and the malnes of the Change wrought in it, which alone creates the Difficulty; and o again, there are many things which as to common Appearance have not their Affects at preent, and which eemingly
act at a very great Ditance of time in the producing them, which yet are o far from dierving to be lighted, upon the core of the ineniblenes of their approach; that on the contrary, they may eem rather to exact o much the greater Portion of our care to be taken, in the better providing and cautioning our elves againt them: the Venome of ome Beats, how lowly, and as it were with deliberation does it teal, and ininuate it elf into the Bodies of uch Creatures, as have at any time been wounded by them; till at lat, it comes to take a full Poeion of the whole Mas of Blood, and Vital Spirits, and brake forth to open Acts of Violence: and yet all the while it hath layn thus dormant, may truely be aid to have as great an Aptitude to detroy, as any the mot deadly Draught of Arenick, or Ratsbane: and the neglect of ome inconiderable Breach, when it hould have been Repaired; how does it in time, occaion Ruine and Detruction to the whole Building.

Herein lies the great Fallacy, which imple People are wont to put upon themelves; they live a Life of Sene, rather than Reaon, or indeed, Fancy rather than Sene; and becaue they don't take notice of any preent Alterations, that may have happened; are the more inclinable to think, that therefore
there have been none at all; and becaue they believe, there have been none for the preent; are ready to conclude, that therefore there wil be none for time to come; and all this proceeds from no other grounds, than want of Judgement, and Foreight; and o being unable, to determine their own Thoughts, by any Solidity of Argument, they are able to make out themelves; are the ooner prevailed upon, by Cutom and Example, to do as others would have them; and willingly uffer themelves, to be gulled and cheated out of their Lives and Healths, only to gratify the humour of the next impertinent Talker, that either comes in their way, or they end for to advie withal; who, o he can but enjoy the delicious Sweets, of having things done after his own way; cares not (it may be) what Michiefs betides thoe Perons, upon whoe Bodies the Experiment comes to be made trial of; which is a matter, I could wih every one that hall have Occaion at any time to be concerned therein, would a little eriouly conider of.

I did ay before, that in cae of the apprehenion of ome great danger, nigh or afar off; which yet could be no other, than that of Death it elf, or ome painful, or grievous Dieae, that might be the Harbinger
thereto; this was a way, that both might, and ought to be ubmitted unto; as upon the Comparion between two evils, the les is alwayes to be choen, becaue in that comparative Sene, it ought to be conceived of, under the Notion of a good: and o may this alo, though in it elf, it be no other than a direct means, to abreviate the Number of mens Dayes, and abridge the Period of their Lives, by Natures Bounty appointed them; as has been manifeted at large.

And though divers are of Opinion, that many after Bleeding, have been much more lively, and vigorous; as alo far more fat and corpulent, than ever they were before; which may eem, to be an Argument of force, to render Invalid, what has hitherto been contended for: let it be but taken into conideration, that all Opinions, that have the good hap to be credited, have not alwayes Truth on their ide; and if it were o, there would not be o many vulgar Mitakes, as uually we find there are; and though it hould fall out, for ome interval of time, to be as is pretended; yet that would evince but little, it being obervable, for ome lucid Interval to happen, even in the mot cloudy Dayes, and ome little Lightning (as they call it) that may be taken notice of, before
the approach of Death it elf; which as it can be no ure mark, to judge the State of the Sick Party by; o neither is it o much to be attended to, how Patients find themelves for a little Space after they have been let Blood; as what the contant Tenour and Condition of their Health, in its full latitude, from that time forward, is commonly taken to be.

The Ram may give ground, but it is with no other purpoe, than to make head again with o much the greater Fury. And Bodily paines, as we find by daily Experience, upon the taking of ome Medicines, have appeared to be prety well appeaed; which yet afterwards, have broken out again, more violently than ever. The Sprigs that are pared from off the Body of the Tree, at ome Seaons of the Year, if but pricked into the Earth, will make a hew to bud and bloome, as fairly to the Eye, if not fairer, than thoe Boughs that have been let alone; but every one is able to give a gues, at the different event, the one is like to have from the other; who has but Reaon to conider, from whence it is, that the caue of this their Flourihing proceedeth: what is deferred, is not for that reaon, to be looked upon, as quite taken away; and an account may be ballanc'd by ums brought in as well at the Rere, as
the Beginning: and further, as touching that ubequent Fatnes, which appears to ome, to have been occaioned upon the core of Phlebotomy: 'tis to be noted, that there is a puffing, and welling up of the Body, exceeding much different from a olid, and ubtantial Nutriment; and though it hould realy prove to be uch as is uppoed, there is no Quetion at all to be made, but that upon a trict Examination of the Matter, a Caue might very well have been dicovered, from the Rules and Principles of Phyick, wherefore to have warranted, a jut taking away of Blood in uch a Cae as that was; which has contantly been alledged of by us. And therefore nothing can ever be inferred, from what has hitherto been allayed, as poken in Oppoition againt any uch manner of Proceedings, but what tends much rather to the jut Vindication of them: it being the rah, heady, and precipitate manner of doing the thing, that we have been endeavouring all this while to expoe, not Blood letting in General, but letting Blood without a Caue, and without taking time to conider, whether it were fitting to be done or not.

'Tis neither Aburdity, nor Contradiction, to condemn the ue of the ame Remedies in ome, and approve of them in others, becaue
the mot general Rules that are, are by no means to pas unlimited; and Circumtances, when different, tand evermore in need of as different a manner of Application. So that what is hurtful in one cae, may be profitable in another; as we find Opium and trong Waters, to be of a ingular ue, when applied eaonably, and with care; and yet the one is known, to be no other than a rank Poyon, is conidered in its own Nature; and the other the wort of Enemies, to the digeting Faculty of the Stomack: and o though the lopping off of a Limb, from the Body of a man, be a mot pernicious thing, and tends apparently to the bane and ruine of that Party, upon whom uch Cruelty hall be exercied; no one ever doubted it. Yet, when a Part hall become mortifyed, and eized on by a Gangrene, then 'tis o far from being accounted o; that the dimembring the man, is one of the highet Acts of Charity, that can poibly be hewn him; becaue the greatnes of the Danger, legitimates the deperatenes of the Cure: and indeed, unles it be in cae of Apparent danger, a hazardous Medicine, ought never to be put in practice, let the Michiefs that acrue thereby, hould prove greater than the Advantage. There is a Rule of Proportion evermore to be oberved in uch
things: and 'tis not the leat part of the Phyitians Office, to hew himelf well skil'd therein: and I ee no reaon, but that a Chyrurgeon, may as well cut a man for the Stone, when he has never an one in his Bladder; or when he is ent to dres a cut Finger, or heal a broken Shin, whip off Peoples Arms, or Legs, without further Deliberation: as a Phyitian in many Caes, that might be named (I don't ay, in all) be dabling with their Blood: the latter being as probable a way, for the doing of their Buines, as the former, though ('tis to be confeed) not altogether o coure, and paineful; as 'tis the ame thing in ome Sene; whether one be mothered to death between Down Pillows, or tortured upon the Wrack; 'tis but a being done to death, either way. And yet there are too many in the World, who are as brisk and flippant at it, as if it were a matter of pure Indifferency in it elf, and left to their ole Power, to intitute how far forth it might be conveniently made ue of, that is to ay, that it might be lawful only for them to have recoure thereto; o oft as the freak took them on the Head, or they had a Mind to have their own turnes erved by it.

And now Sir, having thus liberally paraphaed upon the Preumptions of my own
moddling. I am in the next place to render an account, what the Opinions of others may have been upon the very ame Cae; which when I have faithfully given in, and made ome brief Inquiries thereupon, it mut be left to the Deciion of uch as are unconcerned to pas Sentence upon the Criminate; and declare at whoe Door epecially, the ill Management of the affair ought to be laid; for that there was an Errour committed by ome body, is not in the leat to be crupled at: that being a Conequence, plainly enough deducible from the acknowledgment of us both; and want of Dicretion, is a term of the mallet Denomination, it can poibly be reduced to; becaue upon a full hearing of the matter, as what had been adminitred before his coming; examination of of the Pule, Urine, and uch other like Tetimonies, neceary to be known; we both returned our Opinions freely, and without heitancy, that we aw no reaon at all, wherefore to make doubt of her Recovery: whereas, the Event falling out quite contrary, upon the immediate change of her Medicines, the Fault (I ay) mut be rather his, than mine; becaue altered by his own appointment, and ome of them, againt my likeing; o that, if there were o good hopes, of her Recovery before his coming, to meddle with
her: 'tis trongly to be preumed, he might have continued in the ame probable way till, had he but kept away; and this, I take to be, a fair and a honet Plea, in order to my own Acquittal; let others, clear themelves as they can: I know but one thing, poible to be objected againt it; which has I confes been urged by ome, in a neighbourly way, who have been pleaed, to concern themelves, in the Controvery: That it is a Quality, not at all to be diliked of, in a Phyitian, to be making the bet of another Mans Practice; neither do I ay, it is; only I mut crave leave, to tart a new Query: Whence it hould come to pas, that he, whoe Life was never at any time remarkable, for either the leat ray of Grace, or good Nature, hould become thus trancendently charitable, all upon the puh; o as to be careful, to remove a Thorn, out of another mans Finger, and place it in his own? I hould think an Action of that Nature, to have proceeded much rather from Incogitancy, and want of Foreight; (either of which are unpardonable Blemihes in o great a Phyitian) in regard, when he perceived it begin to prick, and feter, he was o very indutrous, to have retored it back again; but then 'twas a little too late, I thank him: And though it might have been eaonable enough for his
purpoe, was never a whit for mine; and therefore, I am not at all ingaged, to give my aent to it: he, who abolves at one time, can never condemn at another, for the ame thing, though he has never o great a mind to do it, without running himelf upon a Contradiction. Poor Dr. Willis could not, he knew it well enough, when it uited with his own Interet; ele he had never taken the Liberty he did, in playing upon him; though with hame enough, conidering what a Friend he had been to him, he knows where and when, and o do others too: and that may be ufficient, to top the mouth of one, that is not utterly foraken of all modet Principles; but if it hould not, and that he hould till believe himelf, to have the Freedom indulged him, of aying and unaying what ever he judges convenient for his own Deigns, purely, becaue he has to do with a Phyitian, who has his dwelling in the Country. I could put him in mind of a true Story, by which it might be made to appear, that there has been a time before now, when he and I have been of different Opinions, and that when the truth happened to be of my ide too; and if it were o then, why not as well now; but that I am upon my own Jutification; and 'tis a Paage o full of Conviction, o pertinent to the Occaion,
and o exactly fitted to the taking down of a proud Stomack; I hould be ahamed to mention it. It happened ome Years ince, that he was ent into Cambridgehire, to viit a Gentleman of a good Family, who lay ick there; and uch a repute had he gained, from Willis his Commendations, that as full a Belief, was reigned up to his unerring Judgement (as they thought) as ome are wont to allow in Spirituals, to the determinations of the mot Ghotly Father; nor was he les willing to aume, than they to be impoed upon; inomuch, that after a very hort umming up of the Evidence, and there upon perceiving his Cae to be wholly deperate, he bids them neither to flatter, nor deceive themelves with a vain Expectation of what could never be; for that 'twas as impoible for him, to ecape the fatal troke of approaching Death, as for one upon whom the Plague Tokens had already broke forth; and that what he had foretold them, would as undoubtedly come to pas, as the etting of the Sun that night, or the riing of it the next morning, or in words to that effect. And as if this had not been, to have made himelf ridiculous enough, with the ame fale confidence he returns home (and as I have been credibly informed) makes Affidavit of the ame things, in one of the Courts
of Judicature in Wetminiter Hall; though the chief grounds he had for his o doing, to the bet of my Remembrance, was taken from the pitting up of ome mall Quantity of Blood, I imagine that might be a Pleurity of the Lungs too: and for ought I know, make omething the more on my ide; for being o hamefully Wide of the Mark then, as will appear anon; 'tis not unlike, but that the Remembrance of o good a Token upon that occaion, might make him omewhat the more poitive, in preaging this Lady her Recovery now. There are a ort of men in the World, that when ever they have been convinced of an Errour on the one hand; think they can never make any tolerable amends for it, but by diametrically croing over to the other Extream. If any hall ask me, how I came to be o well acquainted with the matter? I have only this Anwer to return them; That the Gentleman his Father and Mother being both my Patients, living at a great Ditance from their Son, and very much afflicted at the news they had received of his ad and deplorable Condition, ordered me to make a Journey over to ee him, and to bring them back word how the cae tood with him; whether when I came, I found him much in the ame Condition he had oberved my Patient to be at Richmond, that is to ay,
likely to do very well again; and o I informed them at my return from him; who were glad with all their Hearts, to find they had been o happily cheated in their Expectations, as the Gentleman himelf was (you may eaily believe) who is ince that time, o perfectly well recovered, as that he may in probability live to ee many wier, honeter, and more healthful men than his Doctor, go before him: and o might this Lady too, for ought I know, had he been o fortunate, as to fall into the hands of one, who had either undertood her Ditemper better, and o known what to have given her, or could have been content at leat wie, to have let her alone with thoe who did, but this by way of Parentheis only. The whole of the Precription next, to the taking away of even Ounces of Blood from her Arm, which has been the matter of o long a Debate, was in the Order immediatly following.

p.U: . Oyl of Sweet Almonds, newly dipened, iij. White Sugar-Candy j. Let them be mixed well together in a Mortar; and let her lick a poonful thereof every third hour.

. the common Pectoral Decoction without Hyop and Scabios lb ij. Let the Liquors trained out, be clarified by Seteling, then train
out for good and all; and of that let her take Draught ever now and then.

. Oyl of Sweet Almonds iiij. Sperma Cet ij. Mingle them together, and make up a • Ointment; with which let her Side be annointed Morning and Evening, putting upon it a Linnen Cloth dipped in the ame, made prett • hot.

. Lyneed Oyl, newly drawn, iiij. Syrup of Maidenhair ij. Let them be mixed together and let her take half this Night, at the time of her ret, and the reidue, either to morrow Night or ooner if there be Occaion.

. Black Cherry Water, Balm Water, An •
iiij. Epidemick Water, iij. Pearled Sugar, a ufficient Quantity, o as to make it moderately weet; let her take four, or five poonfuls of it in her fainting Fits.

div.p:
I have but one Particular more, amongt all thee, to bring my Exceptions againt directly; which is, that of the Lyneed Oyl, and that would be too late to offer now; but that they were likewie made before his arrival, for a Gentlewoman having moved for it, as a Medicine of ingular ue, and now a
Dayes grown into great requet, amongt the Phyitians of the Town; I made bold to reject it then, as unlikely to prove beneficial to her, becaue, admitting it to have been adminitred to uch as were of tronger Stomacks, and more able Contitutions, uch as might be uppoed, upon thoe Accounts, the better fitted for induring a naueous draught; it could not otherwie chooe, but be a little too naty, and fulome for a nice and delicate Lady, epecially at uch a time, when he had been brought to o low an Ebb, as carely to be able to tat the mot pleaant Cordial Drinks, without vomiting them up again, but two to one is too great Odds to be reited with Modety, and the Dr. his Opinion jumping o exactly with hers, I conceived my elf overcome by a Majority of Votes, and thereupon ubmitted to the Ruggednes of the Medicament, though with the ame reluctancy of Mind, as to ome other Directions formerly mentioned.

So that you ee Sir, thoe great Perfectionits, as lofty as their Speculations are, and as much as they would make themelves our Superiours, in the abtruet and mot miterious part of all uefull Learning, are not o deep read neither, but they may have Opinions ometimes, co-incident with thoe of the weaker Sex; and urely when ever it
falls out to be o, the Excellency of their Attainments, upon the Account of which they are o highly valuable, is not to be ought for amongt them, but we are to turn our Eyes to the remaining part of the Precriptions, and examine well the other Particulars, not yet o fully decanted upon, if we expect to find it any where.

And therefore, Dear Sir, do you, whoe Experience is greater, and Judgement more deep, be but pleaed to put on your clearet Spectacles, and try what Succes you can have in the Attempt, and if you are able to dicern what may haply lye concealed from greener Heads; be o courteous as to obliege Mankind with a more full Dicovery thereof: If there be any Mines worth digging into, and Depths worth the fathoming, let the World be made acquainted, with what otherwie it is like, for ever to remain Ignorant of; and uffer not I beeech you o advantagious a Piece of Doctrine as this may haply prove to ucceeding Generations (epecially, in cae of deperate Pleurities of the Lungs) to perih together with its Renouned Author, only for want of a Commentator, learned enough, to have explained the true meaning thereof.

I am omewhat the more impertinent in this my Requet I confes, becaue after the
trictet Search, and mot narrow Diquiition I was able to make into the matter; nothing of that nature appeared ever viible to my hallow Undertanding, nor could I ever yet be convinced, from what I was able to gather from the bet of my own Obervations; but that an Apothecaries Apprentice, or Barbers Boy, if ere a whit towardly, and who had made but o coniderable a Progres in Learning, as to be able to read over Culpeper in Englih, or turn to the Chapter and Section of any ordinary Receipt Book, might have played the Doctor to every whit as good purpoe; I write what my own Thoughts are, poibly to men of a more refined Intellect, and Solider Judgments, the thing may be apprehended otherwie; but I have ever been of the Mind, that the bet way of giving Approbation in what one does, is by endeavouring to act, o as to be the mot clearly undertood; and there are no doubt, abundance of People, up and down the World, that are much of the ame Perwaion; and therefore to me 'tis no wonde • at all, that o many when they come to be cat upon their Sick Beds, chooe rather to commit themelves to the Care of a doting old Woman, or pittiful Emperick, who are known to peak Non-ene at every word, than uch as are learnedly impertinent, and pretend to
give a wie reaon for uch things, as carce any man living can tell what to make of beides themelves, becaue they being convinced of their own wants, and concious to themelves, of engaging in a Province, that does not at all belong unto them, and which others, how ever they are pleaed to imploy them, are privy to as well as themelves, may reaonably ('tis believed) be looked upon, as cautious and timorous men, though they can haply pretend to never another good Quality beides: whereas uch as are puft up with an high Opinion of their own Excellencies, and the greatnes of their Parts, are apt to be intolerable peevih, and humourome, and conceited in what they undertake, venterous at every thing, but crupelous about nothing; and if they do happen upon a right coure at firt, 'tis o much the better for thoe that are to be governed by them; if not, they are to content themelves with Patience, eeing 'tis to no purpoe to argue and dipute the matter, with uch as are reolved to go on in their own way; I am not ignorant what the common Proverb is, Who o bold as blind Bay-yard; and yet a ober man would chooe much rather to be carried on the back of a blind Hore, than a mad one, in cae no better choice could be had, and he that hould do o, of the two,
would be in les danger of breaking his neck; and though it may be a frequent aying, and what is true enough, if taken in a ound Sene, that if a man be appointed to die, he were bet however end his Dayes in following the directions of the Learned, it cannot be denied withal, but that if a man be uppoed to have Learning, which either a Knave, or a Fool has the keeping of (which is a cae, happening out oftner than many are aware of) it may be as convenient every jot to die under the hands of the unlearned, as with him; and upon Suppoition, there be any hopes of Life, 'tis not impoible, but that he may as oon recover too, and perchance with running a far les hazard of o eeing it; the goodnes of every thing conits purely in, its aptitude to the acquiring uch an end, and if that fail once, the Denomination loes its Force, and becomes utterly inignificant. A man may be aid, and that truely enough, to have Learning, which yet may lye o far out of the Road he is to travel in, as to do him but little good for all that, and then he were e'ne as good have none at at all, becaue 'tis no great matter, how little a mans Knowledge peeds, o it runs but deep in the right Channel, and he be but skilful in the Art he makes Profeion of: we read of one, who confeed himelf, a
meer Bungler at fiddling, to whom none ever denied the reputation of a very good Governour notwithtanding, becaue he knew how to make a little City a great one, which was the only thing he ought to have been well vered in; whereas Nero, though an Excellent Muitian, was but a bad Emperour, for his Deficiency in that other Point, o indipenibly neceary to have been undertood by him. Put cae, my Phyitian can make his brags of a ingular dexterity he has, of transferring the Blood of one Matiff dog into the Body of another: if this be the means to harden him in the taking away one Drop more than is convenient from mine, wherein am I advantaged by that Bloody Experiment, though he hould vaunt himelf of his having been frequently converant in the riping up uch poor creatures alone. Recount the pleaant Hitories of his graping their En
•• ils with his hands, and thruting his Fingers into their Hearts, whilt they lay groaning, and panting, and truggling under his knife, (though by the way, I know no Authority, that either he, or any ele have, to exercie any uch Cruelties over them; nay, tho they hould be the whole Colledge of the Virtuoi themelves that tood by, and encouraged him in what he did) but however, whether they have or not, this I am very ure of, that
it is like to prove mall matter of Comfort to any who hall be the Patients of uch a one, to be ere a whit the more ruggedly dealt withal, when they happen to fall under his hands.

Nay though he hould advance a tep higher, and proceed to Pride himelf, in his vide Pag. Tractat. de Cord. Fol. 176. having been the Ring-Leader of the Dance, for the putting Forreigners upon the attempting that upon humane Bodies, which he (only becaue he durt not) had begun to practice upon Bruit Creatures at home; admitting all he ays to to be true, as we have no great reaon to disbelieve him in his Narrative; 'tis a thouand, Pities I ay, but that when it came firt of all to be made trial of, he himelf like another Phalaris hould have given handel to the Experiment; o far am I from enveying him, the honour of o worthy an Atchievement, as ome it eems (the more malicious they) would have endeavoured to have done; but, though they had (to deal impartially on all hands) me-thinks, our modern, Menecrates might have contented himelf with omething les than the Aumption of Divine Honours, as the Recompence of his matchles and indefatigable Indutry, have brought in the Inditement againt the Malefactor, under ome
other Title than that of Sacriledge, and not have preumed to have compared himelf to either Jupiter or Aeculapius for the matter; all which the Alluion mut necearily imply, epecially, when a Reemblance nearer home, becaue taken from Creatures, and thoe of his own Rank and Quality, might have become him far better; my meaning is omewhat of an intermediate Degree between the Butcher and the Canibal; but if nothing on Earth could have been found bad enough for the purpoe, rather than o vile a Micreant hould have acended up into Heaven upon uch an Errand as that, he might with more probablity of peeding, have directed his Coure towards the Infernal Region, to have taken one from thence, which if he had done, and no other could have erved his turn, what thinks he of the Prince of Darknes himelf, who is tiled the Enemy of Mankind, and an Accuer of the Brethren; and then if we do but conult our Lexicons, we hall find < in non-Latin alphabet > and < in non-Latin alphabet > to be terms of no uch ditant Signification, but that they may very well be compatible to one and the elf ame Peron. And he who thorough his Savage Dipoition and narling Behaviour towards all men, has mot deervedly been entituled to the

But when all this is done, and o great a Freedom has been indulged to, unles it could be made evidently appear, which way this happy Invention conduces to the Promotion of the Practical part of Phyick; 'twill be hard to render a Reaon, why uch a remorles Wretch hould take upon him to abue, and undervalue all orts of men he meets withal, only for being les cruel and barberous than himelf. as Spectators when the thing was experimented by another hand; as we ee all orts of People, forward enough to be flocking about the mot butcherly Executioner, what time he is mot buy about his Employment; when yet it may be, there is carce one of all that Number, but would abhor the thoughts of being a chief Actor in the Tragidy; inomuch, that the ame Anwer, which Helena returned to Paris, when he pretended an Exces of Affection to her Peron, above all other men in the World beides, though in omewhat a different Sene, may not unfitly be made ue of, upon this Occaion.

When a Sick Peron comes to tand in need of the Phyitians help, thoe urely of all others are the mot likely to do him good, who may be preumed to ympathize with him the mot feelingly in his Afflictions; whih how hall they ever be able to do as

And here it may be very well worth the taking notice of, that only that ort of Trademen and no other of the whole Nation, are dicharged by the Cutom, if not common Law of England, from giving their Attendances upon Juries, whoe Profeion clearly conits in Blood-hed, though the Calling be otherwie honet, and the Men erviceable enough to the publick Societies they live amongt; which was done no doubt meerly out of a Principle of Prudence, and for fear, let by being accutomed to embrue their hands in Blood, when they had only to do with Beats, and had a jut occaion for their doing o, they might be too inclinable to the like Exercie, after they came to debate about the Lives of Men, and had none at all; and for my part, I cannot chooe but approve of the laudablenes of the Intitution, as believing it to have been founded on the highet reaon,
and am trongly perwaded, that thoe who hall ucceed in the Power of making Laws, will never be able to ee caue, wherefore to alter, or abolih it, there being no uch way of curing an Inconvenience, as by a timely preventing it in its firt Coures, and a removal of all uch occaions, as may eem to have the leat Tendency thereunto.

As there is a Gradation in evil, o is there a tranition and paing over as it were, from one kind thereof unto another; we find it is the Character that is given of the good man, to be merciful to his very Beat: and the Proverb aures us, he that has an unfeigned Love for the Mater, mut have ome degree of kindnes for the Dog: and therefore by the revere of the ame Rule, who ever has arrived to that Pitch of hard-heartednes, as not to know how to pitty a poor dumb thing, whom he has lying at his Mercy; yea, is o far from it, as eemingly to take pleaure in finding out ways of tormenting it, when he needed not, will urely be o much les compaionate to a man, when ever he gets him within his clutches. And therefore, when I am weary of my Life, Id'e end for uch a one to chooe, to conult withal about the uret and mot likely means to be ued in order to my Recovery, but not till then. No
more would others neither, if they undertood what it was they went about: 'tis ttue, when a man comes to die by the hand of the common Executioner, and there is no other Expedient to be found out, for the revoking a Sentence, that has been already pat, then indeed to be backward, in giving a good round Gratuity, for the facilitating ones Paage in the way one is appointed to go, ought to be accounted of, neither as a Part of Pollicy or good Husbandry; but to make Preents to one, who under a pretence of aving my Life, hall in all Probability go the ready way to take it from me, is an Errour on the other Extream, which though many are too apt to run into, yet, few or none wiling to be convinced thereof (it's like) by uch as would be o much their Friends, as to be at the pains to undeceive them; and therefore, when ever uch hall come to uffer upon that Account, as a great many have already done, as they have none to thank for it beides themelves; o is it no great matter, whether or no they hall ever meet with any, that hall be o charitable, as to afford them any great tore of their Pitties. I mut confes, 'twould eem a pretty thing at firt glimpe, and does I believe to many, uch epecially, as are apt to take what ever they hear upon trut, and never make any further
enquiry about it. To have a man dogmatical and pert at maintaining every Poition he layes down at any time by way of Scheam, and Diagram and fetch all the Proofs he makes ue of, from no other Topicks, than thoe of his own Solitary Experiments, Obervations, and Ocular Inpections, which is a coure, ome have taken of late Year, to purchae to themelves a Reputation for Knowing Men, and very uccesful they have been in it, whereby, others who have taken notice of the good luck they have had in uch their Endeavours, have been animated to do the like; and thereupon encouraged not only to obtrude their own wild Fancies, and groundles Chimeres upon the World, ingly by themelves, but to confute one whimical Opinion with another full out as vain, and then to be as grave and erious, when they have been doing o, as if o be they were all the while in earnet, and upon the proecution of ome real and worthy Deign. Whereas indeed and in truth, were the matter but duely weighed, and looked into as it ought, amongt all the everal orts of hameles and phantatick non-ene, we hall meet withal any where, there is none would appear to have been at any time more abuively uch, nor yet vaunted after a more aburd, and ridiculous manner. There is a little
Book intituled, Tractatus de Corde, tuffed from the Beginning to the end, with little ele beides Arguments of that kind; 'twould be an Infinite Labour to enumerate them all: Il'e only give Intance in one of the firt, as a Specimen of thoe which follow, and according to the Etimation taken from thence, may the others reaonably be gueed at.

In Men and uch Creatures, as receive their Nourihment from Fleh (ays that renowned Author) Itaque homini, & Carnivoris fere quibuque Animalibus, Cordis edes non in Centro, ed in uperiore Corporis parte contituta et, &c. vide Pag. Tractat. de Corde, Fol. 2. The Poition of the Heart is never found exactly eated in the very Center of the Body, but rather omewhat above it, to the intent, it might dipoe of what Blood hould be convenient to be ent up to the Head, o much the more eaily; for eeing that the forcing up, and Ditribution of the Blood, depends altogether upon the Contraction of the heart and the Liquid Subtance thereof, is not of its own Nature o freely carried upwards, as to the Parts directly Oppoite, or which are placed beneath it. In cae the Scituation of the Heart, had been further from the Head, it could not have been poible, but that that mut have been more compactly framed, o as to have ent it up thither with a greater
Force, or ele the Head would ometime or other have wanted Blood for its own Support. Fieri non poet quin aut ipum robutius formatum, &c. mut have been jut o. Bold audacious man, as if o be the Almighty could poibly have contrived no other ways for the bringing his own Works to perfection, but what were exactly undertood by him; or that by his diecting of Hearts, and the Obervations made thereupon, he had arrived to uch a Degree of anatomical Experience, as to be able to view Knowledge in that particular, with the very Searcher of Hearts himelf: 'tis uch a proud kind of Expreion, as one hall eldom, or never hear from a Chritian man, had the thing been never o certain, much les in a matter abolutely fale and ridiculous, as will appear in the further Examination of it; as I do not ee wherein Menocrates his < in non-Latin alphabet > , though a Heathen, and for which he was accounted bereft of his wits, can tand chargeable of greater Arrogance. But to proceed; In Animalibus autem qua longiori Collo, & quai ad victum porrecto donantur, &c. But as for uch Creatures as have longer Necks than uual, which are the Intruments with which they ••• d their Hearts are as far ditant from their Heads, as any of the ret of the Parts of their
Body beides, and that without any thing of Dammage to them at all, becaue, for the mot part, they uck their Food with their Heads hanging downwards, o that though the Blood may have farther to pas in them, than in ome other Creatures; yet it is a convenience of a much plainer, and far more eay dicent.

Whether this conceit be his own or not, is foreign to my enquiry, and but the ame thing to him neither, becaue if it be not his own, he thereby dicovers the wretchednes of his Judgement in epouing it, as not having wit enough to dicern where to pilfer with the greatet afety, in collecting matter, for his little Treatie: if it be the wretchednes of his Fancy, for lighting on no better; however, I for my part have no reaon, but to uppoe it to be his, becaue he is o willing to have it thought o, and therefore, I hall crave leave to demand of him, after what other way and manner, he would have either them, or any other Creature ele, to feed themelves (ome very few only excepted) then by hanging down of their heads, though not for the imple reaon alleadged by him, to wit, that the Blood might by that means, o much the more freely pas into their heads; but becaue their Eyes, which were their Intruments of eeing,
were placed there, which urely is omewhat more than his were, when he treated upon that Argument, he would never ele have blundered o egregiouly at his firt etting out if he had.

And that may pas very well for one final Caue, and another omwhat like to that may be, becaue their Mouthes, which are their Intruments of Eating, are placed omewhat thereabouts to: And there being a neceity for the Nourihment firt to be taken in at the Mouth, before it can come at the Neck or Stomack, to be dipered up and down the Body, for the Sutentation of each Member: 'Tis pretty clear, that all Creatures almot, that are debarred from feeding on Fleh, will be contrained, either to reach it from the Surface of the Earth, or fih for it in the Waters, becaue they mut eek for it ome where or other, where it is to be found; and then if they cannot bring their Food to their Mouths, mut be glad to bend their Mouths and their Necks too, whether they be long or hort, down to their Food, unles they can be content to be famihed to death for want of it.

Beides, the reaon thereof can never poibly be that alledged by him here, upon other far different Accounts, becaue if he be well Remembered,
he teaches us ele where, Pag. 133 (or if he had not, it would have been no very hard matter, to have informed our elves) that the motion of the Blood in 'its full latitude, depends originally upon the Arteries, and is driven by their pulation even from firt to lat. Cum enim certiimum it, Sanguinis Venoi refluxum, non ab attractione Cordis ulla, ed a propulu arterioi Sanguinis provenire, facile et concipere, quantum partium quoque itus ad facilit andum, aut retardandum hunc motum conferat. Veluti enim in homine, cum in Pedes erigitur, Sanguis a Venis Jugularibus, & Vena Cava decendente, citius & facilius uo quai pondere in Cordis Sinus delabitur (imili modo atque Venae in Manu elevata moxvacuae, in demia vero turgidae & plenae cernuntur) qui vero et in Partibus inferioribus, & Vena Cava acendente difficilius, & contra Naturam uam, olum abarterioo Sanguine verus Cor propellitur, & Vi quadam urgetur, in planum autem jacente Corpore Sanguis aeque facile ab utrique redit.

For eeing it is mot certain, that the flowing back of the Venal Blood, does not at all depend upon the Artraction of the Heart, but rather upon the Succeion and coming on of the Arterial blood; 'tis eay to apprehend
how much the ituation of the parts conduces either to the facilitating or retarding of that Motion; as in cae of a Mans tanding upright upon his feet, the Blood tumbles down with a much freer Coure, and more natural propenity from the Jugular, and hollow Vein decending into the Ventricles of the Heart, as we may ee by a hand lifted up, the Veins art oon emptied, but in the ame let down again, as oon woln and full; whereas that which is beneath the Heart, and returnes by the Way of the hollow Vein acending, is wrought up with much greater Difficulty, as being againt Nature, and only by the forceing on of the Arterial Blood, but when the Body lies tretched upon a Level, the Blood then is reconveyed from either part alike.

By which words, it plainly enough appears, that nothing with a long Neck, can ever be put in any great danger of having a Bloodles Head, any more than a body et upon a long pair of Legs (a witles one indeed, ome with a hort one may, epecially, whilet they argue no better to the purpoe about that Subject) becaue if there were need of o trong a Spring to jerk it up to the Head that tood perched upon the long Neck, by the very ame reaon, there would no les • orce be required for the ending it
up the lower Limbs of that Body which had the long Legs belonging to it. And therefore as ome in railery are wont to et the Haires Head againt the Gooe Giblets, o may we upon very good grounds, oppoe the long Legs to the long Neck, becaue, there is the ame reaon for the one, that there is for the other, neither greater nor les; for as the Blood mounts the Head with Difficulty, o it lides down again with eae, and on the contrary, as it falls into the Feet of it's own accord, it mut be forced back again to the Heart with o much the greater Labour, it will never arrive thither ele, becaue conveyed back not at all by the atraction of the Heart, but by the forceing on of the Arterial Blood, Cum certiimum it Sanguinis Venoi refluxum non ab attractione Cordis ulla, ed a propulu Arterioi Sanguinis provenire. And then if there be uch a neceity for the making the heart more compact for the ake of the long Neck, why not as well upon the account of the long Legs, in regard the Arteria magna acendens & decendens, both receive their Original from the ame Stock, and conequently tand in need of equal Aitance for the performance of the Offices unto which they have been each of them appointed? And as that Party, who is to travel a Hill jut backward and forward, and no more, is at
an Indifferency as to the whole of the journey he undertakes, whether he be to begin at the bottom or the top firt. So 'tis all one, whether the Blood, when it be to leave the Heart caeteris Paribus, fall downwards into the Feet, or acend upwards inro the Head, Provided its Paage be looked upon as not compleated, till it return to the ame part again; unles we will ay, that he who commences his Journey at the bottom of the Hill, is contrained to encounter with the greatet hardhip of all at the firt part of his way, which is to be recompened by a proportionable Alleviation at his coming down again, whereas he that takes the contrary Coure, has only the advantage of the mot pleaant part of his Journey at his firt eting out, and the wort at lat; which amounts upon a true cating up, to jut nothing at all.

'Tis not to be denied, but the Blood does pas with a great deal more difficulty from the Heart to the Head, than from the ame place to the capillary Arteries of the Feet, but then if it be conidered, how teep the acent from the Feet to the Heart is back again, and contrarily, how natural the retreat from the Head is to the ame Region of the Heart, after it has once gained the vertical Point; there will be no better way, of adjuting the Calculation than by etting one againt t'other:
and then this eemingly learned Dicoure wil be reolved into a Parcel of pureelf-Contradiction, and the great Anatomit convicted to have written he knew not what, in the matters appertaining to his own Art. I have heard indeed of long billed Brids, that would be apt ometimes to bewray their own Nets; but never before, of any with long Necks, that unles they tooped oftentimes would be indanger of the Staggers.

Beides the Aertion is manifetly untrue in Practice; there is no uch thing in Nature, as that long necked Creatures hould be any more obliged to toop down with their Heads and Necks, than others are; and thoe that will but take notice, hall oberve the Swans, to wim along with as erected Necks, as either the Teale or the Dab-Chick; and if I mitake not, to be diving with them as eldom, and tho a Hore has a much longer Neck than a Bull, I don't ee he carries his Head ere a whit the les tately for all that, but rather the contrary, and if he can but be allowed an able Rider to manage him, may be prevailed withal to hold it o from Morning till Night; which had the other Poture been altogether o neceary as is pretended, would carcely have been poible; beides one would much wonder, that the great Hore-Maters, who have pent o
much of their time, and hard tudy about uch niceties; hould none of them have been Anatomits enough to have undertood o much before; and that the Grooms and Otlers, who have evermore profeed uch great kindnes to Hores, hould be uch wicked Knaves, as to delight in tormenting them thus cruelly, when they needed not, by caueing their Racks and Mangers to be et at uch an unreaonable Height, and forceing them to do Penance in a manner for every morel of Hay they eat. And yet the greatet wonder of all is till behind, whence it hould come to pas, that the Hores that are kept at home, and have all this Injury done them, hould look o much fatter and fairer, and be o much fitter for Service, then thoe that are turned to gras all the Year about, and permitted to feed themelves after their own way with their Heads hanging down, and their Blood by that means, freely taking that Coure which Nature had appointed it. But to be erious, though they hould hold down their Heads longer than others, to make the utmot conceion Imaginable, that could never do neither; And unles they were uppoed to keep them in that Poition for a Contancy, there mut be ome wier reaon ought out for, then what is taken from the more eay conveyance of the Blood thither;
becaue otherwie their poor Heads would be in a Bloodles Condition; however, there needs no other Argument to prove the Conequence, than what hall be taken from the ame Author his own words in another place of the ame learned Treatie, for if we look forward to the 156. Page. and o on, we are informed that a Quantity of Blood equal to the whole Mas, paes through the Ventricles of every Mans Heart, at let ix times in an Hour; and how that the ame Proportion is likewie to be oberved in all other Creatures. Atque ita e habet in omnibus Animalibus, &c. So that if one half of the Blood, or but neer o much, be to be dipoed of by the upper Branch of the Aorta, as there is no quetion to be made, but that it is; if thee long Necked Creatures he mentions, hould chance to forget themelves never o little, and forbear holding down their Heads but one Minute of an hour; what an unequal Ditribution thereof, mut necearily enue upon it, and how would all the faculties of the uperiour Region of the Body be at a los for want of Spirits to act withal, by reaon of the Head its being in o great a meaure disfurnihed of them, according to this Hypotheis? And yet we ee they do forbear for a great deal longer time, and that frequently too, without any the leat hew of Prejudice
or Inconvenience to them at all; which is a manifet Indication of the Author his being mitaken, in the Doctrine he delivers, as he is indeed in almot every thing he any where treats about; inomuch, that etting aide the Dele totum at the Begining, which he is pleaed to place amongt the Erratas, (though others, full as knowing as himelf, are of opinion they deerve much better, and to be reputed of as the onely piece of wholom Advice, that is to be found in the whole Book) there are carce two words coming together, that may not upon very good reaons be found fault withal; but what is that to me, if it hould be o; who am only concerned to look to my elf, and make good my own Station? 'Tis no uch delightfull Recreation to me to be buying my elf about other mens matters, and calling them to an account for what they have done; could I have been permited to have enjoyed my own quiet, and lived free from Moletation at home, I hould have been paring enough of giving them the leat Diturbance in any of their Fooleries, let them have been never o many, or never o egregious. And now I have been put upon it contrary to mine own Inclinations; o little deirous am I of eeking after advantages of that kind, that I am herrtily orry for the Occaion offered me of
aying o much as I have; tho in the greatet plenty of argument. As I have been all along hitherto upon the defenive part, o I deire to hold on till. And if I can but ward off my Adveraries Blow, and hinder him from doing me the Michif he deigns, hall never be at all olicitous about the following of my own, to the incommoding of him though I had it never o much in my power to do o; becaue 'tis the clearing up of my own Reputation, as it falls in with the General Deign o often intimated; and not the diparagement of his that I have a repect unto; and if that might have been effected by a direct Coure; as there would have been little need of cating Peronal reflections upon any man, o hould it never have been offered at by me. 'Tis true, I could have deciphered ome Body plainly enough to be undertood, who has been exceeding fortunate at etting up with a borowed ingenuity, when he has had but a very inconiderable Stock to have made a Beginning withall of his own, made vat improvements of the precarious comendations betowed on him by ome great ones who have been charitably dipoed, See Mr. Fr. Potter his Letter to I. A. Equire, of the Middle Temple, written in the Year 52. By which is made to appear, who was the firt In • enter of the transfuion of the Blood He ued to ay, it came into his Mind by reflecting on the Story • f Medea and Jaon. and having bin related to a numerous ociety of Men evermore good at
crying up a few of their own Members for trancendent in each particular Faculty, whither happening to deerve it or not. And though I am pretty well aured, there is not any thing can be more taking with the Vulgar, than to be hewed a Mater Wit in his own conceit, turning Mater Fool at lat, in the Opinion of all others beides himelf: and that Multitudes of imple People, who have uffered themelves to be deluded, by the fale Appearances, and idle Pretences of the ame Peron's imaginary clerkhip, could like it well enough to be rectified in their Judgements, by receiving ome better Information concerning him; yet for me he is like to tand in the ame fair Opinion with them he alwayes did; not only becaue it looks o unhandomly, and makes o harh a Dicord, to be aying all the Ill one can of a Peron, from whom one has ometimes heard Ill, but becaue of the Advantage that is given againt the Truth thereby: to uch whoe Aent is more truely valuable: by ideing with it o uneaonably. Recriminations we all know to be none of the bet means of defending a Caue by, o far indeed from gaining the party who makes ue of them, any acquittal from the Fault he tands charged with, that they rather make one, where there was none before; at leatwie, bring uch an one under a trong Preumption
of being thought guilty, who otherwie might have paed for Innocent. But yet as Commendations, violently extorted from a mans own Mouth, when wrongfully accued, are wont, amongt equal Judges, to meet with omewhat a more favourable cenure, then to be looked upon under the trict Formality of elf praiing; o on the other hand, it may well be hoped, that they who have deired to live in Peace, and could not obtain it: when they come to be injuriouly dealt withall, and hardly poken againt without Caue, may be allowed the Previledge of making their Apology after the bet (not to ay only) manner they can; and then if they do now and then reflect upon their Adveraries Infirmities, when it could not be otherwie avoided (provided it be done with Truth and Sobernes, not o much out of Anger and by way of Retaliation; as in order to the Invalidating the malicious Suggetions they find have been whipered againt themelves; or for the prevention of publick Wrongs and Inconveniences, that in all Probability, without ome uch Coure taken, might have been offered to others) deerve omething of a conivance, at leatwie, if not to be held abolutely excued; as for my own part, it cannot be denied, but that I have now and then let fall ome harpih expreions
againt a Peron of Eminency enough in his own profeion; for if no Body had been intended thereby, it had been a pouring out wotds to no purpoe, and an aiming them at Random; but then I conidered with my elf, before I did o, how he came by it firt of all, and what excellent good ues, he has made of it ever ince, and does dayly; what ort of People his cheif admirers are and have been, and how they likewie came to be o, and by what meanes and artifices they have been continued in their Belief: and the thorough Apprehenion of thee things, made me I confes, omewhat the more bold, than otherwie I hould have been.

I abhor the thoughts of deigning any thing of prejudice either to a good Man, or a good Mans Friend; and as I am not under any obligation of aying all the ill I can of uch as are neither, o am I not wholly to keek ilence upon a jut Provocation offred. There may very well be a ditinction made between the Man and his Baenes, and a Charity preerved for the one, and yet none at all for the other. Not that I am forgetful where I have declared the chief Motives prevailing with me to engage in what I have done, to be taken from the conideration of more Publick concerns than any thing relating to my elf, and o they were
And yet that ought to be no hinderance to me in the aerting of my own Jut Rights; Or treating about other Particular Matters in time and place convenient. Becaue thee are things implying nothing at all of contrariety but oft time, a great deal of Agreement with, and ometimes Subordination to one another. And 'tis not impoible but that an Example may be ingle and multiplied at the ame time, only by a different manner of apprehending it. So that what's Acted by one Man, may be approved of by one hundred; and the others wanted but an Opportunity for the doing of the ame things. And therefore I could wih with all my heart, as it has been the drift of what I have propounded to my elf from firt to lat, that when ever the Decription of any Mans actions or Demeanour hall have occurred in any former Paages of mine, including any thing of ingratefulnes in them; as 'tis impoible but that if an ill thing be Acted, it mut be Acted by ome body, it may however be undertood in an abtracted ene; and by the help of the Intellect til reduced to ome uch Order of Men whoe either Folly or Naughtines may bet Intitle them to uch a Charracter; and that will ave me the trouble of heaping together multitudes of Examples for the Confirmation of what I have been all this while endeavouring
to make good. Only one Intance more of my one knowledge, ince the acting of what has been o largely related, comes in o patly to my purpoe, that it mut and will, whether I will or no, be a little taken notice of. Il'e umme it up in a word or two, and then conclude.

A mot Ingenious, and learned Gentleman (and if uch can be impoed upon, what are we to believe of others) and one that I have had everal times under my hands upon the account of the elf ame ort of Ditemper, was taken uddenly ill of a Flatulency in his Hypocondria and Bowels; the Illnes was apparently ubdued, as it had been oft-times before and that with much the ame kinds of Remedies; and all the Aurances given o far forth as humane foreight would extend to, of a Speedy Recovery, without the leat grounds or fear of any poible Danger. And yet upon the arrival of a London Phyitian, blooded he mut needs be, nothing would erve his turn without it, which before he could obtain, he was forced to beg and entreat hard for: I am ahamed to ay how long time together, & rather than have none at all, he would be contented with a very little Quantity, ome two Ounces, or thereabouts; and leat he hould mis of that mal Pittance too, was glad to take it away with his own hands.

Many illy reaons were pretended upon the core of the Scurvey, Jaundice, and Sharpnes of Humours, and the like; but the Principle, and the only true one, never o much as mentioned at all. To wit that no other, after that had been done, might be capable of putting in for a hare of the Cure beides himelf: all little and inferior Remedies, being as it were lot, and wallowed up in the great one; and being once able to ay, he had fetched Blood of his Patient, away he went immediately with a great deal of Complacency and Satisfaction.

Sir. I beg your Pardon for the tediounes of this Addres, and making ue of a Cae you have been o nearly concerned in; as likewie for the publihing of both, without either your Knowledge or Order. As to what relates to others, I have made my Apology ele where, and therefore, there will be the les need of aying much now in this place. The Office of an Informer was a thing I never much delighted in, and all uch as know me aright, wil I believe bear me witnes as to the truth of that Particular; I am Concious of too many failings of my own to be over cenorious of other Mens; and as for Peaceablenes of Demeanor, I don't know that ever I b • gun a Quarrel with any Man in my whole Life; of all the Phyitians that
ever lived in England; I dare ay, few ever were wore ued by Empericks, and Quakalvers, and thoe of the vilet, and mot depicable ort if any of them can be aid to be more uch than others, then I have been: and yet I cannot call to rememberance, that I have had my Paions at any time very much tranported beyond the Bounds of Moderation; and therefore urely, I have litle reaon to countenance uch men, to the depreing of honet and able Phyitians; neither have I at any time, if my words may be contrued in their true Gramatical Sene; and thoe who Judge of them otherwie, may pervert any mans honet Intentions as well as mine, and o are little to be regarded.

Such as pretend to be of a Profeion, they know nothing of, and were never in the leat fitted for, may be, and doubtles are exceeding bad men; but thoe that degenerate from the honet Principles belonging to their own are a great deal wore. And that's the utmot my words can amount to, taken in the mot rigorous Acceptation imaginable. There are Conciones ad clerum as well as ad Populum; and if Divines may be allowed to peak againt Divines, and tell them of their Faults when they do amis out of the Pulpit, why may not the Members of other Faculties be allowed to imitate them upon a like Occaion?
I confes, the gravet and wiet Perons are the bet qualified for the performance of uch an Office. But if they out of prudentiall coniderations, bet known to themelves, hall think good not to be een therein, rather, than to have it wholly omitted; I for my part ee no reaon to the contrary, but why it may be done by others.

Not that I am altogether ignorant what are the uual conequences attending upon publick Reproofs. And how ticklih a thing it is to be dabling in a ore place, not inferiour for tendernes to the Apple of an Eye. I expect no other than to be called to a evere account for what I have written, and am as ready to give it, provided my Auditor prove to be ober and ingenuous. But if a Sot or a Buffoon hall take upon him to be Pragmatical, tho I think I may be bound in concience to pitty uch a one for his folly, or rudenes, and it be for no other reaon than out of a conideration of humane Infirmity, yet do not look upon my elf to tand obliged, by that, or any other tye whatever, to make any Reply to him in either, be his Language never o mouthy or never o provoking.
